Award.AwardTitle: Pan American Advanced Studies Institute on Electronic Properties of Complex Systems; Cartagena, Colombia; June 6-17, 2011
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Pan-American Advanced Studies Institutes (PASI) award, jointly supported by the NSF and the Department of Energy (DOE), will take place on June 6-17, 2011, in Cartagena, Colombia. Organized by Dr. Adam Wasserman of Purdue University, the PASI will bring together top theoretical and experimental scientists from four different fields centering on the fundamental question of how electronic properties of complex systems are determined. Spectroscopy, electronic transport, laser chemistry, and multiscale modeling will be discussed with the goal of establishing the most significant open problems in these fields. The format of the proposed PASI, with a mixture of classes, lectures, round-tables, and poster sessions, will encourage approximately forty participants to be fully engaged in the process of understanding the main problems and suggesting novel strategies to overcome them.

Lecturers/researchers will be drawn from the Americas and Europe, and will include graduate students and post-docs from throughout the Americas. Among the expected outcomes of this PASI is the establishment of new collaborations between scientists in the U.S. and Latin-America and the promotion of nanotechnology education and research efforts in the hemisphere. Results from the PASI will be disseminated through a website where all the lectures will be made available.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Pan-American Advanced Studies Institute on Electronic Properties of Complex Systems held in Cartagena, Colombia, June 6-17 2011, brought together a group of about 75 participants from the US and Latin-America to discuss fundamental open questions in the field of experimental characterization and theoretical description of electronic properties of complex systems. Through interactive question-answer sessions, round tables, group work, and a poster session held at the University of Cartagena, new connections between participants were established, providing opportunities to strengthen the scientific connections between the US and Latin-American countries in the field of electronic properties of complex systems.

During the two weeks of the workshop, fifteen leading experts gave pedagogical lectures focusing on three main topics: (1) Spectroscopy of complex systems (session coordinator, Prof. Alex Fainstein, with lectures given by Profs. Eberhard Gross, Alberto Castro, Shaul Mukamel, Bob Continetti, and Weitao Yang); (2) Laser chemistry for optimal control of chemical reactions (session coordinator, Prof. Alberto Castro, with lectures given by Profs. Herschel Rabitz, Leticia Gonzalez,  Jose Luis Sanz-Vicario, and Victor Batista) ; and (3) Electronic transport through single molecules and nanostructures (session coordinator, Prof. Caio Lewenkopf, with lectures given by Profs. Gianlucca Stefanucci, Latha Venkataraman, Jeff Neaton, Marcel Mayor, and Eberhard Gross)

A complete list of the topics covered, talks and information given by the lecturers is posted on the PASI webpage: www.cursopasi.unal.edu.co (also available at: www.purdue.edu/dft/pasi).
